description.narrative:
The project will provide equity financing to a systemic bank in Guatemala, generating a range of social, economic benefits:
(i) Promote banking penetration and inclusive business in the Central American countries (Guatemala and El Salvador)
(ii) Increased Financial Sector Stability: IFC's funding will contribute to the industry stability in Central America by increasing funding for a growing regional player.
(iii) Funding diversification: IFC term finance will improve BI's asset and liability management (ALM) and provide additional funding diversification.
(iv) Access to SME finance in Central America: IFC's long term funding will be critical in supporting the growth of the SME lending in the region. The project is clearly a great opportunity for IFC to engage with a regional player with a clear capacity to reach and create an impact in the development of best practices of SME lending in the region.

It provides a comprehensive range of corporate and retail banking, insurance and other financial services to over 1.7 million clients in the region. Banco Industrial in particular, is the banking arm of the group that provides commercial and retail financial services in Guatemala and El Salvador, and the target of IFCs proposed investment. The opportunity available for IFC is to support Banco Industrials operations in Guatemala and El Salvador through an investment comprised of: A regional credit line for up to US$ 190 million in the form of straight senior long-term loans allocated, US$ 175 million to Banco Industrial Guatemala, and US$ 15 million to Banco Industrial El Salvador, to be used to finance SMEs, and climate smart and; An advisory services component targeted to support Banco Industrial Guatemala on its objective to enhance its capacity on Sustainable Energy Finance.

Currently it provides services through a network of over 1,600 service points throughout the Republic of Guatemala, as well as electronic access from anywhere in the world. BIGT has one of the largest banking distribution networks in Guatemala, according to the Guatemala Superintendence of Banks, serving more than 1.3 million retail clients and 7,100 commercial clients. BIGTs importance is also reflected in its major role in the countrys payment system. Banco Industrial El Salvador initiated operations in 2011 when it was granted a banking license to operate in El Salvador. BI ES is the 11th largest in terms of assets and loan portfolio in the banking sector. As of December 2015, the bank owned 8 retail branches and had 123 employees in the country. BI ESs focus is on corporate lending with a strong participation in the manufacturing and services sectors.
